thread.title: Unlikely stars, and another American win in Presidents Cup
thread.title_full: Unlikely stars, and another American win in Presidents Cup

author: DOUG FERGUSON
title: Unlikely stars, and another American win in Presidents Cup
text:
AP Photo Unlikely stars, and another American win in Presidents Cup 
US team captain Jay Haas (left) and his son Bill address a press conference after they defeated the International team 15 1/2 to 14 1/2 to retain the Presidents Cup at the Jack Nicklaus Golf Club Korea, in Incheon, South Korea, Sunday, Oct. 11, 2015. Lee Jin-man Unlikely stars, and another American win in Presidents Cup 
US team captain Jay Haas, front centre, poses with his team after they defeated the International team 15 1/2 to 14 1/2 to retain the Presidents Cup at the Jack Nicklaus Golf Club Korea, in Incheon, South Korea, Sunday, Oct. 11, 2015.(AP Photo/Lee Jin-man) Lee Jin-man Unlikely stars, and another American win in Presidents Cup 
International team player Anirban Lahiri of India reacts on the 18th green after missing a putt to lose his match against United States' Chris Kirk in their singles match at the Presidents Cup golf tournament at the Jack Nicklaus Golf Club Korea, in Incheon, South Korea, Sunday, Oct. 11, 2015.(AP Photo/Lee Jin-man) Woohae Cho Unlikely stars, and another American win in Presidents Cup 
International team player Sang-moon Bae of South Korea reacts after a shot onto the 18th green during his singles match against United States' Bill Haas at the Presidents Cup on the Jack Nicklaus Golf Club Korea, in Incheon, South Korea, Sunday, Oct. 11, 2015.(AP Photo/Woohae Cho) Lee Jin-man US holds on to win the Presidents Cup 
United States' Chris Kirk, left, celebrates after sinking a putt on the 18th green to defeat International team player Anirban Lahiri of India 1up in their singles match at the Presidents Cup golf tournament at the Jack Nicklaus Golf Club Korea, in Incheon, South Korea, Sunday, Oct. 11, 2015.(AP Photo/Lee Jin-man) Ahn Young-joon Unlikely stars, and another American win in Presidents Cup 
US team captain Jay Haas, left, embraces his son Bill after he won his singles match to defeat the International team to help retain the Presidents Cup golf at the Jack Nicklaus Golf Club Korea, in Incheon, South Korea, Sunday, Oct. 11, 2015.(AP Photo/Ahn Young-joon) Lee Jin-man Presidents Cup, Capsules 
International team player Sangmoon Bae, right, of South Korea congratulates United States' Bill Haas on the 18th green following their singles match at the Presidents Cup golf tournament at the Jack Nicklaus Golf Club Korea, in Incheon, South Korea, Sunday, Oct. 11, 2015.(AP Photo/Lee Jin-man) Ahn Young-joon Unlikely stars, and another American win in Presidents Cup 
International team player Sangmoon Bae of South Korea is consoled by his caddie Matt Minister on the 18th green during his singles loss to United States' Bill Haas at the Presidents Cup golf tournament at the Jack Nicklaus Golf Club Korea, in Incheon, South Korea, Sunday, Oct. 11, 2015.(AP Photo/Ahn Young-joon) Woohae Cho Unlikely stars, and another American win in Presidents Cup 
International team player Branden Grace of South Africa watches his chip shot on the 16th hole during his singles match against United States' Matt Kuchar at the Presidents Cup on the Jack Nicklaus Golf Club Korea, in Incheon, South Korea, Sunday, Oct. 11, 2015.(AP Photo/Woohae Cho) Ahn Young-joon Unlikely stars, and another American win in Presidents Cup 
United States' Phil Mickelson reacts after chipping onto a green during his singles match against International team player Charl Schwartzel of South Africa at the Presidents Cup golf tournament at the Jack Nicklaus Golf Club Korea, in Incheon, South Korea, Sunday, Oct. 11, 2015.(AP Photo/Ahn Young-joon) Unlikely stars, and another American win in Presidents Cup Associated Press | 
INCHEON, South Korea (AP) — The final hour when both teams thought they had it won. The clutch putt that turned a rookie into the hero. The stubbed chip that made the local star cover his face with both hands as if he wanted to hide. 
The Presidents Cup, packed with raw emotion and endless nerves, was unlike any other over the last 10 years. Subscription Required An online service is needed to view this article in its entirety.
